citations.narrative:
A thick buildup of grime, urine and brown organic material was located throughout the indoor enclosure floor housing a
ring-tailed lemur. Not cleaning these areas, and by allowing grime to accumulate, can pose a disease hazard for the
animals. Per the regulations, hard surfaces with which nonhuman primates come in contact must be spot cleaned daily to
prevent accumulation of excreta or disease hazards. If the species scent mark, the surfaces must be sanitized or replaced
at regular intervals as determined by the attending veterinarian in accordance with generally accepted professional and
husbandry practices.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
In the indoor enclosure housing a male lemur, an excessive number of fruit flies were observed flying in and around the
food bowl. Pests can transmit disease, contaminate food and surfaces, and can harm animals. An effective program for
control of insects, external parasites affecting nonhuman primates must be established and maintained so as to promote
the health and well-being of the animals and reduce contamination by pests in animal areas.

The indoor enclosure housing two racoons has an excessive accumulation of feces, urine and brown organic material on
the enclosure floor, and wire mesh caging. There is also an immediate overpowering stench of urine, feces, and ammonia
present. Failure to clean excreta from primary enclosures as often as necessary can lead to disease and contribute to
odors. The licensee must ensure the primary enclosure is cleaned and excreta removed on a routine basis and as often
as necessary to minimize disease hazards and reduce odors.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
